Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Project: Building An Innovative Smartphone Virtual Laboratory Environment for Cyber-security Education and Training

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a collaborative effort involving Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis, Rochester Institute of Technology, and Tennessee State University. The investigators are taking a comprehensive approach to advance smartphone security research and education. The approach includes collaborative virtual lab design and implementation, curriculum development, faculty professional development, and partnership development.

The investigators are developing and building a Smartphone Virtual Computing Laboratory (SVCL), which caters to Computer Science, Information Technology, and Computer Engineering undergraduate and graduate students' intellectual curiosity and complements their anecdotal knowledge of mobile and cloud security. The SVCL provides an interactive and collaborative learning experience to students by allowing them to work on interesting and challenging projects derived from current research. With SVCL, students can work together, anytime, anywhere, which, in turn, helps them foster a constant learning habit that will benefit their careers. Using smartphone security as the unifying theme, the investigators are developing hands-on laboratory modules from latest research on smartphone application (app) security, smartphone operating system (OS) security, smartphone cloud security, and smartphone network security. They will also host workshops to disseminate the curriculum materials to faculty at other institutions.

Through these efforts, the project aims to expose students to latest research on smartphone and cloud computing security. The project also aims at delivering a repository of teaching/learning materials on smartphone security that allows students to learn, work, and explore together through ubiquitous access to the virtual learning and experimentation environment, SVCL. The background of the institutional collaboration (public, private, and HBCU) brings greater diversity to the pool of student participants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this proposal is to design and implement a Smartphone Virtual Computing Laboratory (SVCL) that enables and engages CS, IT, and CE students to work seamlessly and collaboratively on interesting yet challenging projects derived from latest research on smartphone security, anytime and anywhere, based on virtualized smartphone and academic/commercial cloud computing facilities.

The objective of the modules is to analyze the behavior of malware affecting smartphone’s operating systems to break the app isolation and escalate the app’s privilege. The objectives also included analysis of the behavior of malware affecting smartphone applications and smartphone cloud interface. The modules have been deployed in undergraduate and graduate courses.

The major activities included development of  modules focused on Smartphone Security which will allow students to learn about the nature of attacks on Android and iOS systems, privilege escalation, tools used to analyze the attack and the approach to detect these attacks. We evaluated multiple hardware/software facilities in order to host the virtual lab environment. We also setup cloud services to host emulators of the Android smartphones on the clusters. We have configured the access control and authentication mechanism on the clusters in order to provide collaborative service for the virtual lab. Modules focused on smartphone application security, smartphone network security and smartphone cloud security have also been developed. These modules allow students to learn about the nature of attack on smartphone applications, network and cloud, tools used to analyze the attack and the approach to detect these attacks.  We also conducted a variety of smartphone attack analysis and identified a couple of typical attacks. We have determined several potential virtual environments and Android images for the lab experiment. We also investigated the feasibility of conducting Android experiments on the Global Environment for Network Innovations (GENI).

We collected a large number of Smartphone Malware samples from multiple research projects. We have developed a prototype which allows the execution of malware in the virtual copy of an Android device. We can easily change the version of the smartphone OS and the hardware specification of the smartphone. For each of the three modules, we have developed a prototype that allows the execution of malware in a smartphone and collection of system and network events for analysis. We surveyed smartphone attacks and their detection and protection mechanisms. The project has provided a better understanding of the feasibility of conducting smartphone security attacks on a virtual environment. We have also identified several key lab experiments through the attack analysis in the project and started to implement them.
